ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The class reviews the key American and European theorists in the field of Human Rights--with a strong focus on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Human Rights treaties and law. The class materials are Euro-centric and therefore interesting if European thought and history is your field of interest.
Yes, it is a generally good course on human rights history, however with a very strong theoretical element

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I would have liked it to help me with my field of study, but it did not. I took the course because I study a non-European region that has been deeply impacted by human rights abuses but we did not spend any considerable amount of time on non-European countries and therefore it was difficult to relate the class discussion/readings to my own work.
The course helped me to complete my comparative master's research
